children.html:
Hello {first_name, "there"},

Well, that was one hell of a week. The first week of teaching at City in my new, enlarged role has kept me busy, alongside my existing slate of training and consultancy. But, because you're worth it, dear readers, rather than knock off early for a glass of whisky and the latest episode of She-Hulk: Attorney-at-Law I'm bringing back a feature of the site that's fallen into neglect.

children.text: was very popular when I started it back in the early part of the year. Then events rather overtook me, and it dropped off my agenda. Well, now it‚Äôs back, should be weekly ‚Äî and with
, it should be a really useful source of information about what my audience really carer about ‚Äî while also being useful to you.

This is a bit of a tab-dump issue. There are stories here going back over the last few months ‚Äî but doing that has drawn out some interesting narratives, not least that Meta‚Äôs Facebook and Instagram are clearly losing their way. We‚Äôll get to that towards the end, but for now ‚Äî enjoy these links. Hopefully, there should be something here for everyone. If not, I recommend whisky and

‚Äî this is rare for Meta. Normally, they push forward with changes even if people dislike them. Are they losing sight of what their users will actually tolerate?

Based on the links above, Meta‚Äôs future is looking more uncertain than I can ever recall. As

But look at the past few weeks of Meta news and it seems like the company has zero idea of what to do or why people use its products. It made drastic unlikable changes to Instagram; its leadership is panicking over TikTok; its latest public demonstration of its metaverse future is embarrassing and its educational value is less justified than the VR headset in a thirty year old Simpsons clip. Do these decisions look like the product of a focused company that has near-term goals for its future and innovative ideas beyond that?

? Certainly ‚Äî if we want to be on TikTok. The question that needs answering first is whether we should trust TikTok, given its ownership‚Ä¶

If you dare to be female while writing about the countryside, this is what you get. A group of men speculating about your pubic hair. Anyway off to do my job - yes, women are allowed to have those nowadays! pic.twitter.com/qYiqzalyXZ

— Helena Horton (@horton_official) October 7, 2022

children.text: But the internet is still here and there might come a day when things get decentralised again. I don‚Äôt know if that might ever come to pass, but for now, we can take back the internet by going back to creating our own websites and blogs and even newsletters and relying less, far less, on the cursed social networks.
This is, admittedly, a couple of months old, but i finally got around to reading it this week, and it does make some very compelling arguments. Do you agree?

metadata.title: Yes, Social Media Really Is Undermining Democracy
metadata.description: Despite what Meta has to say.
metadata.author: Jonathan Haidt

children.text: Journalists love news. It's axomiatic, really. But our readers don't tend to love news as much as us. Our obsession with chronicling every detail of the rolling waves of crises over the past five or six years initially helped drive sales up ‚Äî but is now becoming a problem.
We need to address this, but without abandoning our core mission.

metadata.title: When tragedy becomes banal: Why news consumers experience crisis fatigue
metadata.description: The sensitivity involved in attending to crises can be a double-edged sword.
metadata.author: Rebecca Rozelle-Stone

Thanks for reading, and have a great weekend, folks.

Adam
